properties.title: Prediction of Deposition Free Energy of Organic Crystals Using OSRW
properties.author: Ian J. Nessler

subsection.name: Prior to using the Osrw interface
subsection.p: In order to use the Osrw interface data depicting the atomic coordinates and connectivity of the compound are necessary for proper usage. Currently accepted data formats include:

The difference between a xyz and a pdb format is the way the information is portrayed. Both formats tell the script information on coordinates and atom type. The following is an example a xyz file containing 26 atoms:

Each data file contains information on the xyz coordinates of each atom, the type of each atom, and the which atoms are bonded to each atom. This information is in a crude form that osrw will not be able to interpret. The data filename that is listed serves as a marker to a property file with the same filename that holds information necessary for running the script.

A property file provides general crystal information, the name of files used for patching, and/or force field options. When using Osrw the property file has the extension filename.key. It is important that the data file name and the properties file name are the same. An example of a property file may look like this:
subsection.source:
parameters Compound.patch patch Compound.patch
spacegroup p-1 a-axis 3.8000 b-axis 6.770 c-axis 21.650 alpha 82.30 beta 83.99 gamma 81.98
vdw-cutoff 12.0 polar-eps 0.01 polar-sor 0.65
integrate stochastic
subsection.p: In the property file there should be a pointer to a patch file. The patch file provides in-depth information on the atom type, multipole effect, torsion angles, bond angles, and biotype of each atom. This is a small section of the patch file detailing the biotype for each atom.

subsection.p: Once all this information is acquired in a file with the extension .patch along with the property file and data file a trial can be run on Osrw.

subsection.name: Running Osrw
subsection.p: When the script is run it tries to acquire both the data file and the properties file. If the properties file is not under the same filename as the data file then an error will occur while the program evaluates the script causing the program to shut down.

When running the script there are a couple of recommended flags that need user input on every trial. These flags are:
-s
-f

The -s and -f flag are used to relay information to the program depicting which atoms will be allowed to move along the alchemical path. -s for the starting atom and -f for the final atom to be moved.

subsection.p: There are many variants of the script that can be used to tailor the way a trial is run. Many of these flags have a default value listed. There are some that need user input before the trial can run, for example, -f has a default value of <-1>. This value will cause the script to crash and must be replaced before the script is run

subsection.name: Analysis of Results
subsection.p: A job that is running may take several days to come to convergence. Depending on the different flags used the time the script should run will vary. A simple way to tell when a program has converged is to analyze the histogram. Every job that successfully runs will produce a histogram saved as filename.his. When the histogram is opened it should look like this:

This is only part of the histogram specifically from 0.048 lambda to .153 lambda. The whole histogram is a representation of the results from 0.00-1.00 lambda. A smaller part of the histogram has been shown for convenience. To tell if this job has converged the dG or derivative of free energy with respect to lambda column should not vary by more than 1. Due to Osrw's sampling methods there may be a larger variance around the edges of the lambda parameter but as long as the vast majority of the dG values are within the allowable variance then the test has converged.
